top_comment.text:
I don't think the message of kindness is simplistic.  Sometimes we wrongly 
assume that kindness is equivalent to weakness.  Sometimes being stern with 
someone is a measure of kindness in a sense that it is for their own good. 
 If you're concerned about children misinterpreting the message, well 
that's where the parents come in.  Sometimes you don't want to over 
complicate things when they are very young and allow them to calibrate 
their perspective as they get older.  Also it should be noted, that 
Cinderella's mother (or who I assume is her mother), told her to "have 
courage and be kind" and "where there is kindness, there is goodness, and 
where there is goodness, there is magic".  I don't think that is overly 
simplistic.  If anything it's rather cryptic and begs implies there's 
something more to the message. It's so easy for us in today's society 
especially, to be cynical about everything.  And sometimes that can work 
against us.  ﻿
top_comment.author: levar1979

comments.text:
Cate Blanchett and Kenneth Branagh both said recently that in an age of all 
these super hero movies they wanted to explore the idea of Kindness being a 
super power. That its not that kindness will always prevail, but more along 
the lines of what do you do with kindness. I think the angle is that 
Cinderella survives this horrible ordeal because she keeps her kindness in 
check and never stoops to her step-family's level. My father used to say, 
"taking the high road eventually takes you to a higher place" which seems 
to be the case for this movie. What do you think? Could Kindness be a super 
power?

Yes ladies, if you're being abused stay there and be kind. Maybe some dude

top_comment.author: KC Nwaneri

comments.text:
You have to take into account the time period. Back then women just didn't 
have the same rights as we do now. Her step mother and sisters also spent 
much of her fathers money. So she had no where to go and no money to get 
there. It's not just about being kind but also having courage. In an 
interview I believe it was the director who said she wouldn't be a push 
over in this movie. It's a fairy tale at the end of the day and the basic 
message is just to be a good person and push through the tough times.
comments.author: sratrat78

comments.text:
+KT Chong

I agree with KT Chong 100% Its just a movie based off of a fairy tale it 
isn't suppose to be real. I don't think the intent is to teach girls that 
being kind only will get you out of an abusive situation any more than they 
are trying to teach girls that fairygodmothers are real.

But if you must find a message in a movie based off of a fairy tale then I 
want to point out that in my personal opinion people should be kind even in 
a horrible situation, But I don't think being kind in the real world means 
you are a doormat, you can be kind and assertive. I think being able to 
live through something like abuse and still being kind and not turning into 
a horrible person like those who were abusing you is a virtue.

And thirdly for all those complaining that this is teaching girls to stay 
in abusive situations, the fact that she stayed is probably the only thing 
even remotely close to reality about this fairy tale movie, if I am not 
mistaken for the time period this is set in there wasn't anywhere for her 
to run away to. Maybe perhaps a work house where she wouldn't have been 
treated any better.
comments.author: 1yugioh11

comments.text:

comments.author: KT Chong

comments.text:

comments.author: Linn Carol, MD

comments.text:
I agree, kindness will not free a co-dependent martyr from abuse.  A person 
should strive for fairness and respect . . . not "kindness".  Tolerance of 
abuse and disrespect is not a virtue.  Being a doormat will not earn 
respect or rewards.  The the Disney CInderellla story encourages a 
dangerous, self-defeating mind-set.  "Ever After" did the story justice.  
Danielle (Drew Barrymore) was a character who was admirable and 
respectable.  The Disney Cinderella is talking to mice, her sanity is 
questionable.  It is possible that the prince, fairy godmother, and the 
ball were all a false reality her psyche developed as a coping mechanism.  
In reality, the Disney Cinderella would wake up and find herself still 
locked up in the attic.
comments.author: Linn Carol, MD

fairytales, so it's not that it's not my thing, I'm just a bit disappointed 
in the way this is looking...﻿

captions.text: the magic will only last so long
at the last stroke of midnight
and all will return to what was before...
The ragged servant girl is what you are.
And that is what you will ALWAYS be.
So this is where you take refuge.
I bet you have never ever spoken to a man!
You shouldn't be this deep in the woods alone.
I hope to see you again, miss.
It was my mother's old dress, you see?
You shall NOT go to the ball!
Let me slip into something more comfortable.
For you SHALL go to the ball.
It fits! It fits! IT FITS!
Where there is kindness, there is goodness.
And where there is goodness, there is magic.

title: Cinderella 2015 International Trailer + Trailer Review : Beyond The Trailer
